tit.cmt: タイトルなので説明訳括弧を削除しました。

sen.j: 張り子、あるいは張子（はりこ）とは、竹や木材などで組んだ枠、または粘土で作った型に紙などを張りつけ、成形する造形技法のひとつ。
sen.e: Hariko is one of the plastic arts technique which forms papier-mache by attaching pieces of paper to frames made of bamboo or wood or molds made of clay.
Hariko is one of the plastic arts technique which forms papier-mache by attaching pieces of paper to frames made of bamboo or wood or molds made of clay.
Hariko is one of the plastic arts technique which forms papier-mache by attaching pieces of paper to frames made of bamboo or wood or molds made of clay.
It is also called "Haribote."
It is also called 'Haribote.'
sen.cmt: 原文の「」に合せて"を'に訂正しました。
sen.e: It is also called 'Haribote.'

sen.j: 張子に用いられる紙は「混凝紙（こんくりがみ）」（「混凝」はコンクリートの意味）と呼ばれる。
sen.e: Paper used for the papier-mache is called konkurigami (konkuri means concrete).
Paper used for the papier-mache is called 'konkurigami' ('konkuri' means concrete).
sen.cmt: 原文の「」に合せて'を補足しました。
sen.e: Paper used for the papier-mache is called 'konkurigami' ('konkuri' means concrete).

sen.j: 張り子の技法は室町時代頃に中華人民共和国から伝来したとされている。
sen.e: It is said that the papier-mache technique came down from the People's Republic of China in around the Muromachi Period.
It is said that the papier-mache technique came down from China in around the Muromachi period.
sen.cmt: period 小文字にしました。原文の「中華人民共和国」が時代的に誤りだと思うのでChinaとしました。
sen.e: It is said that the papier-mache technique came down from China in around the Muromachi period.

sen.j: 日本全土に分布し、郷土玩具などに用いられている。
sen.e: It spreaded around Japan and has been used for such as folk toys.
It spread around Japan and has been used for such as folk toys.
It spread around Japan and has been used for such as folk toys.

tit.j: 張り子の技法を用いたもの
tit.e: Things that use the papier-mâché technique
Things that use the papier-mâché technique
Things that use the papier-mâché technique

sen.e: Chochin (Japanese paper lantern)
Chochin (Japanese paper lantern)
sen.cmt: 不要なスペースを削除しました。
sen.e: Chochin (Japanese paper lantern)
Daruma doll
Daruma doll
Daruma doll
Inuhariko (papier-mache dogs)
Inuhariko (papier-mache dogs)
Inuhariko (papier-mache dogs)

sen.j: 江戸時代に成立した郷土玩具。
sen.e: Folk toys created in the Edo Period
Folk toys created in the Edo period.
sen.cmt: period 小文字にしました。
sen.e: Folk toys created in the Edo period.

sen.j: 犬は1回に複数頭の子供を生み、出産も他の動物に比べて軽いことなどから安産や子供の健康を祈願する守りとして用いられた。
sen.e: As a dog breeds many puppies at a time and its delivery is quicker compared to other animals, it is used as an Omamori (a personal amulet) for anzan (easy delivery) and baby's health.
As a dog breeds many puppies at a time and its delivery is quicker compared to other animals, it is used as an Omamori (a personal amulet) for easy delivery and baby's health.
sen.cmt: anzan日本語読みは不要と考え削除しました。
sen.e: As a dog breeds many puppies at a time and its delivery is quicker compared to other animals, it is used as an Omamori (a personal amulet) for easy delivery and baby's health.
Koboshi (self-righting doll)
Koboshi (self-righting doll)
Koboshi (self-righting doll)
Akabeko (traditional toy of red cow)
Akabeko (traditional toy of red cow)
Akabeko (traditional toy of red cow)
Tora (papier-mache tigers)
Tora (papier-mache tigers)
Tora (papier-mache tigers)

sen.j: 虎の形をしている以外は赤べことほぼ同じ。
sen.e: It is almost the same as akabeko except for its shape of a tiger.
It is almost the same as akabeko except for its shape of a tiger.
It is almost the same as akabeko except for its shape of a tiger.

sen.j: 威勢ばかりで中身の伴わないことを指す「張子の虎」ということわざの語源となっている。
sen.e: It is used as the root of an expression, "hariko no tora"(papier-mache tigers of which neck swing), which means a person who is in high spirits but superficial.
It is used as the root of an expression, 'hariko no tora' (papier-mache tigers of which neck swing), which means a person who is in high spirits but superficial.
sen.cmt: 原文の「」に合せて"を'に訂正しました。
sen.e: It is used as the root of an expression, 'hariko no tora' (papier-mache tigers of which neck swing), which means a person who is in high spirits but superficial.

sen.j: ひょっとこ、おかめなどの面
sen.e: Masks such as Hyottoko (clownish mask) and Okame (plain-looking woman)
